comments.commentBody: That is a rather crass comment, although did the phrase "law degree" escape your notice? Also, these days women also help support the family.

Sounds eerily like the movie starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson, "Send Me No Flowers." Except, the diagnosis in the movie was for a doctor's other patient, not the one (Rock Hudson) who thought he was going to die by overhearing his doctor describing that other patient. Like the movie, it seems to me that it's not your job to find a partner for your wonderful husband, Jason. Perhaps you will recover and survive, and you and Jason can continue your long-lasting love affair.

Such a beautiful gift you are giving the love of your life. I lost the love of mine a year and a half ago - a similarly sounding blissful marriage to an amazing man. He too gave me his blessing on the hopes that I would be able to love again. While it may take your husband time, i have to believe that life goes on. I'll never love anyone the way I loved my husband - and his love stays with me to this day. There are so ma y signs from him that he continues to be near me. I wish you a safe journey to the other side and pray for your everlasting connection with your husband to continue as mine does.
Unlike most Times readers, I see only sadness here, and no larger purpose.

I have been contemplating of late what it would be like to have had a last message from my brother or sister (who I lost within seven months of each other nearly 4 years ago).  Perhaps not for me but for their spouses and their children. Not that my loss is less but I will always have had more years with them. This gift of these words (and of course the sentiment) are without measure. I wish you peace and gentle passing as you savor however you can these last days with your family. I wish them all the love possible and your husband that gift of more love you seek for him. Thank you.

Your eloquent message to Amy touched me as much as her essay did. As a nearly 62 year old woman who has never married and never experienced the kind of love you both describe, I cannot possibly know your loss. But, I can have profound respect and admiration for the ways in which you both have honored the men that you love.

I couldn't be touch reading this real love letter.
My husband and great love (James, same fist letter then yours:-) pass away 2 years ago in the same way. Its was so painful but in other way so beautiful too. His spiritual trasfomation teach much me and evrebody who was around at that time.
I'm Brazilian and probably never meet your Janson but in the Heaven you don't have this barriers, than, please hug strong my James for me. He was American (California guy), it will e easy find him.

Martin and I were married of for 30 years. And I am doing what you and Jason are trying to do. Imagining the next 30 years. Martin died unexpectedly in his sleep at 54 just four months ago. I used to say that marriage is hard and I would never do it again because I thought I would get 30 more years. I am more fortunate than most to have known the many things you describe in our life as well. I am trying to move forward with grace, peace and the love. The letter you have written here is something that Jason will be able to read over and over and over when you have left the earth and your kids. Love is patient, love is kind. And it never ends. My best to you in your journey, and let the stars light your way.

I dated a man for 5 years who had lost his "other half" to ovarian cancer. All I can say is that its a hard act to follow. I think it was more in my head to understand and honor the woman I had never met except in photos. It was hard for the kids as well even though they were in their 20's.
Although you want to reassure him and yourself that he will be taken care of, I advise you to let him grieve and develop his "independence", if you will. The man I was with did not take this time and it ended up dividing us. A man as wonderful as you describe will right his ship and sail forward in time according to the natural path of deciding when the time is right. Please allow him the space and time to do that. He needs to separate you and his past with you and be ready to negotiate the next part of his life. That takes a few years. I am sure from what you have written that he will be OK and do this with the help of your fine family.
At this point enjoy what time you both have left, tell him it's OK with you tht he grieves for you and that you trust him to decide to move on only when he is ready.
A cyber war wont work against people with notebooks.
Uh IT Security Engineer here.  Thats the dumbest thing I've ever heard :D
Kim might be thinking about what happened to Saddam Hussein and Iraq. It would be ideal if the Peninsula could become one country again, but the ship might have sailed some time ago.

You seem to be confused, please allow me to clarify.

1. My post indicates I am well aware of the scope of the danger of North Korea. I will add that I can run off a litany of bad acts by history's bad men from Jackson and trail of tears to Stalin's purges to Ariel Sharon's Sabra & Shatila Massacre.
2. My tone and words demonstrate that I dismiss the inflated danger of N. Korea, as such your suggestion I may be cowering indicates you did not read my comment.
I'm less concerned with what Donald puts in his mouth as I am regarding the words that come out of his mouth.
So true, maybe if he stuffs it with steak and ketchup and Big Macs and taco bowls, there will be less fake news coming out.
Let's take a break today at President Donald's White Castle.
Batten down your hatches, sir.  Donald has just -begun-.  He is our Tweeting President.

Excellent article.  Cancelling the Labor Department's proposed fiduciary rule will be a big mistake. Improvements in 401k rules to increase participation, reduce excessive costs and require employers to offer plain vanilla, low cost index funds are badly needed in order to make up for the decline of defined benefit pension funds.
There are fees for the other accounts - just not the guaranteed interest fund.

Amy, what a gift you have given all of us this morning. To read about such love in the midst of a so many stories of hateful events is like diving into the ocean on a  hot summer's day. It cools the mind, and revives the soul. I hope you are able to get through the comments. We are all out here singing with one voice, "Thank you and bless you", Jason, too!

I worked for the Cleveland Public Schools (CPS) from early 1979 thru mid-1982.  At some point during that time, they began offering a deferred comp program to their employees (I was a clerk, not a teacher).  I distinctly remember that the rep who met with interested employees would offer to find an amount that you could save--pre-tax--that still allowed you to bring home the same amount of money.  That was a very attractive inducement and likely what happened to the original poster.
All the best and good luck. Really.
Love between people is unique and special... And becomes more special and rare with time.  Glad the author and her husband have been able to share this.

I am trying to get my head around what it takes to write a piece such as yours as tears rush in. The courage and the honesty, humor and pain that came through your fingertips and onto the page. It is one of the most beautiful, amazing, liberating and heartbreaking essays I have ever read, and I sit here in awe and frozen in heartbreak for you and him and your children. YOU are extraordinary, and he is an incredibly lucky and amazing man. I don't think I will ever be quite the same as I was before reading Modern Love today.
Actually it did clearly say that he has a law degree and works 9-5 most days. However, I'm sure with your "pleasant" comment, he wouldn't look at you otherwise. No worries.

"It is better to remain silent and be thought a fool, than to speak and remove all doubt"

Abraham Lincoln

It's
Life.
Not morbid.

I'm with Ron. One of the insurance industry's big lies about "investment products" is "you don't pay me, the firm does." If you want to get a decent idea about an agents commission just ask "how much will I get back if I want to get all my money out the first year." This "surrender charge" is often the exact amount of gross commission paid by the insurance company.
If you want advice that is more likely to be in your best interests ask your advisor if they are ALWAYS required to act as your fiduciary - then ask for it in writing. Bet your insurance salesman will refuse to do so.
What a disappointing reaction.
